Baba Yaga gave the cauldron to Tasha when Tasha announced her desire to explore the multiverse, to help her in her travels. However, the cauldron was so heavy Tasha was forced to leave it in Baba Yaga's chicken legged hut. Baba Yaga assured Tasha she would come if Tasha ever needed to use her cauldron, allowing the ancient witch to check up on her daughter.

Tasha bristled at the thought of leaving such a powerful item with her mother, but it was too heavy to move. Tasha called on her adopted mother as sparingly as possible until she was able to create a permanent lair in the Lost Caverns of Tsojcanth. The cauldron served her well for the years she ruled a vast empire from the caverns, but it was lost when Tasha was forced to flee when armies of allied nations brought her empire to ruin.

entries.name: Random Properties
entries: Tasha's Caudron has the following random properties:

items: 2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Beneficial Properties|dmg|minor beneficial} properties
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Beneficial Properties|dmg|major beneficial} property
2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Detrimental Properties|dmg|minor detrimental} properties
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Major Detrimental Properties|dmg|major detrimental} property

entries.name: Arcane Focus
entries: You may use it as a spellcasting focus as long as you are within 20 feet of it. Three times each day, when you use it to cast a spell, the cauldron can produce the material components for the spell, worth up to 100 gold pieces. These material components disappear after the spell is cast, whether or not they are consumed by the spell. Uses for this ability recharges at dawn.

entries.name: Potion Brewer
entries: You can perform an 8-hour ritual to create one dose of any of the potions listed in Chapter 9 of the Dungeon Master's Guide. The cost of creating potions through this ritual is halved. You can have three potions brewed this way at once.If you brew a fourth potion using the cauldron, then the oldest potion turns to water permanently.

entries.name: Poison Master
entries: You can perform an 8-hour ritual to create one dose of any of the poisons listed in Chapter 8 of the Dungeon Master's Guide (pg 257-258). The cost of creating poisons through this ritual is halved. You can have one dose of poison brewed this way at once. If you brew a second dose of any poison using the cauldron, the older poison turns to water permanently.

During the ritual you can choose a command word. The poison looks, tastes, and acts like water until you speak the command word within 100 feet of it. The poison does not convert to its true form if it has been administered to a creature or consumed by a creature, or if you or the poison are within a {@spell silence} spell or {@spell antimagic field}.

entries.name: Cauldron's Legion
entries: Once each day you can perform a 1-hour ritual to summon a demon of your choice. This ritual requires rare ingredients, worth 500gp for every level of Challenge Rating the demon has (minimum of 250gp). These ingredients are then consumed by the ritual. At the end of the ritual, you make an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check, with a DC equal to 5 + the CR of the summoned demon. On a failed check, nothing happens. On a successful check, the demon appears floating in the space above the cauldron and must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC.

On a failed save, it is {@condition charmed} by you and under the effects of a {@spell geas} spell for 1 year. You can order it to complete one task for you, which it is magically compelled to do. After completing this task, the demon returns to the Abyss.

On a successful save, the demon is {@condition restrained} and {@condition grappled} by magic bonds above the cauldron for up to 1 minute. It can use its action to attempt a Strength saving throw to break free of these bonds. The DC for this saving throw is equal to your spell save DC. It can return to the Abyss at will, or magically returns to the Abyss after 1 minute.

Only one demon can be summoned or under your control through this ritual at a time. If you try to use this ability on a second demon, the effect immediately ends on the first demon. The first demon will know of this and will be free to plot its revenge.

entries.name: Pierce the Veil
entries: Three times each day you can perform a 10 minute ritual to cast the {@spell scrying} spell using the cauldron. The cauldron can target creatures or areas not on the same plane of existence as you, and ignores the effects of any spell of 8th level or lower that prevents scrying, such as the {@spell nondetection} spell. If the targeted creature or area is under the effects of a 9th-level spell or other magical effect that prevents scrying, you must make a DC 19 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check. If you succeed, your {@spell scrying} spell ignores the protective magic. If you fail, the {@spell scrying} spell fails and is wasted.

entries.name: Destroying Tasha's Cauldron
entries: Destroying Tasha's Cauldron is one of the most difficult prospects in the multiverse. Tasha must be slain, and her body placed into the cauldron. You must then perform a special 8-hour ritual that drains the magic of the cauldron, resurrecting Tasha. She will be furious at the destruction of her cauldron and will teleport away to plot her revenge. Baba Yaga will also know the cauldron was destroyed and will come to check on her adopted daughter.

item.name: Tenser's Folding Disk
entries: This fine grey cloth, soft as silk, is folded up to the dimensions of a handkerchief. It unfolds into a circular sheet 3 feet in diameter.

You can use an action to unfold the Tenser's folding disk, activating the {@spell Tenser's floating disk} spell imbued within. The fabric circle then functions as the plane of force created by such a spell, and lasts until you use your action to fold the disk or attunement is broken.

item.name: Tome of Animal Understanding
entries: This volume, titled "The Languages of Beasts," allows you to learn how to communicate your general ideas with animals. If you spend 48 hours over a period of 6 days or fewer studying the book's contents and practicing the nuances it contains, you can speak with any beast as if you were under the effects of a {@spell speak with animals} spell.

item.name: Trick Cards
entries: When you or another creature draws a card from this deck of standard playing cards, you can control which card is drawn.

item.name: Unseelie Dagger
entries: This black dagger confers some of its unseelie darkness on its targets. Once each turn when you hit a creature with this weapon, you can choose to curse the creature until the end of its next turn. The cursed creature has {@sense darkvision} with a radius of 60 feet, and has disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight whenever it, its target, or the thing it's trying to perceive is in sunlight.

item.name: Vajra's Antiwand
entries: This wand radiates antimagic and cannot be used as a spellcasting focus. Originally created for law enforcement officers of Waterdeep that were frustrated with magical criminals, copies have been leaked to the public. Owning such an item is illegal for private citizens in some municipalities.

This wand has 3 charges and regains {@dice 1d4 - 1} expended charges each dawn. A creature holding the wand can say a command word to cast {@spell counterspell}, {@spell dispel magic}, or {@spell nondetection} for 1 charge, or {@spell antimagic field} with a duration of 1 minute for 3 charges.

item.name: Wereboar Necklace
entries: This necklace is made from teeth taken from a living wereboar and strung onto silver wire in a cruel ritual. While attuned to this item, you can use your action to polymorph into a {@creature giant boar}, as if by the {@spell polymorph} spell. The necklace does not meld into the boar form, but changes size and remains around the boar's neck. Once used, you cannot use this ability again until you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Curse
entries: The necklace is cursed and becoming attuned to it extends that curse to you. As long as you remain cursed in this way, the necklace tightens around your neck and cannot be removed except by a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic. While cursed, you are vulnerable to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage from silvered weapons. Whenever you take bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from any source, you must succeed on a DC10 Constitution saving throw or else take an additional {@damage 1d4} slashing damage as the necklace digs into your skin. If you fail this saving throw by 5 or more, you contract lycanthropy and become a wereboar.

item.name: Xanastone Ring
entries: This ring is adorned with a small crystal that glows with a rainbow light and is attuned to a specific elemental damage type (acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder). The ring has 5 charges, and all expended charges are regained each day at dawn. When you hit with a weapon attack, you can expend 1 charge to add {@dice 1d4} of the ring's elemental type to the damage roll.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Wisdom modifier from your Armor Class.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Charisma modifier from your Armor Class.
While wearing this armor, you can subtract your Intelligence modifier from your Armor Class.

This weapon is adorned with small black spikes that seem to soak up any blood that splashes across them. This acts as a +1 weapon and provides you with {@dice 1d8} temporary hit points whenever you reduce a Dragon, Giant, Humanoid, or Monstrosity to 0 hit points.

This armor is forged of cold iron, a magical material that protects the wearer against fey magic. While wearing it, you have advantage on saving throws against the spells and other magical effects of fey creatures, as well as on saving throws to resist the memory loss caused by the feywild.

This weapon is made out of cold iron, which is toxic to fey creatures. When you hit a fey creature with this weapon, it deals an extra {@damage 1d6} force damage. The fey also has disadvantage on saving throws to avoid being banished or otherwise returned to the feywild until the end of your next turn.

Mithral is a light, flexible metal. If a weapon normally has the Heavy or Two-Handed properties, the mithral version doesn't. If a weapon normally has the Finesse property, the mithral version also has the Light property.

spell.name: Behold
entries: You test the confidence of a group of creatures before the gods by conjuring a vision of the upper planes. Each creature in a 40-foot cone in a direction you choose must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 5d6} radiant damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn by the incomprehensible glories that it sees. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition stunned}.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the size of the cone increases by 10 feet for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Conjunction of Air

m.text: an item originally from a plane of air, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of elemental air in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. For the duration of the spell, all creatures gain a flying speed of 30 feet while inside the cylinder. A creature that is still in flight when the spell ends floats safely to the ground, as if by the {@spell feather fall} spell.
When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can cause one of the following effects:

items: The cylinder fills with magical silence. No sound can be created within or pass through the cylinder. Any creature or object entirely inside the cylinder is immune to thunder damage, and creatures are {@condition deafened} while entirely inside it. Performing verbal components of spells is impossible within the cylinder. This silence lasts until the spell ends, you dispel it as a bonus action, or you fill the cylinder with magical amplification.

The cylinder fills with magical amplification. Creatures within the cylinder make saving throws against effects that deal thunder damage with disadvantage, and nonmagical objects and structures become vulnerable to thunder damage while inside. Spells that can normally only target creatures can also target nonmagical objects and structures within the cylinder. This amplification lasts until the spell ends, you dispel it as a bonus action, or until you fill the cylinder with magical silence.

You compress the air in the cylinder. Each creature in the cylinder must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 3d6} thunder damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

spell.name: Conjunction of Chaos

m.text: an item originally from a plane of chaos, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of chaos and entropy in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. That area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: Whenever a spell originates in the cylinder, there is a 25 percent chance that a random effect from the {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB} table replaces the spell's intended effect, and a 25 percent chance that one occurs immediately after the spell is cast as well. The Wild Magic Surge table can be found in Chapter 3 of the Player's Handbook, under the description of the Wild Magic Sorcerous Origin.
Each time a creature moves 5 feet within the cylinder, there is a 50 percent chance that it moves in a random direction instead of the intended one.

spell.name: Conjunction of Dawn

m.text: an item originally from a plane of light or rebirth, worth at least 10gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of light and rebirth in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. That area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: Creatures in the area have disadvantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded} and effects that deal radiant damage. Celestials are immune to this effect.
Spells cast within the cylinder that restore hit points function as if they were cast at one level higher than the spell slot used.
If any of this spell's area overlaps with an area of darkness created by a spell of 7th level or lower, the spell that created the darkness is dispelled.

entries: When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can target a creature in the area with one of the following effects:

items: If the creature has died within the last 10 minutes, it is restored to life with 1 hit point.
You end one disease affecting the creature.
The creature's {@condition exhaustion} level reduces by 1.
You end one of the following conditions affecting the creature: {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition poisoned}, or {@condition petrified}.

spell.name: Conjunction of Earth

m.text: an item originally from a plane of earth, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of elemental earth in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can cause one of the following:

items: The surface of stone, dirt, and any other earthen area within the cylinder liquifies and becomes sticky, turning into difficult terrain. A creature that starts its turn on such a surface must succeed on a Strength saving throw, or become stuck to the surface and be {@condition grappled} until the start of its next turn. A creature {@condition grappled} in this way has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws. When the spell ends, this grapple ends.

Stone, dirt, and other earthen surfaces within the area buck wildly. Each creature on such a surface must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 4d6} bludgeoning damage and be moved 10 feet in a random horizontal direction within the cylinder.

entries: This spell has no effect on structures.

spell.name: Conjunction of Fey

m.text: an item originally from a plane of fey or dreams, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of fey and dreams in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. For the duration, all nonmagical plants and beasts in the area are given intelligence and movement, as if by an awaken spell. They lose this benefit when the spell ends or if they leave the cylinder.
When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can cause one of the following effects:

items: Each creature within the cylinder must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} by or {@condition frightened} of you (your choice when you take the action) for the duration of the spell. A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Fey automatically succeed on this saving throw.

Each creature within the cylinder must succeed a Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious} for the duration of the spell. Attempts to wake creatures sleeping in the cylinder automatically fail. A creature who is {@condition unconscious} can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. A creature that succeeds on this saving throw is immune to magical sleep for 24 hours. Fey are immune to this effect.

You summon a {@creature swarm of sprites|TCEE1} in an unoccupied space of your choice within the cylinder. These sprites are hostile to all creatures in the area that are not Fey, and disappear when the spell ends or if they leave the cylinder.

spell.name: Conjunction of Flame

m.text: an item originally from a plane of fire, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of elemental fire in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. For the duration of the spell, all creatures within the area make saving throws against effects that deal fire damage with disadvantage.
When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can cause one of the following effects:

items: You magically conjure {@dice 1d4} {@creature magma mephit||magma mephits}, {@creature smoke mephit||smoke mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit||steam mephits} (your choice) in unoccupied spaces of your choice within the cylinder. They are hostile to all creatures that are not elementals and act on their own initiative count. These mephits lack the Summon Mephits action. A mephit summoned in this way disappears when the spell ends or if it leaves the cylinder.
You mentally command all mephits summoned by this spell to immediately die, triggering their Death Burst traits.

You ignite all flammable objects within the cylinder. Creatures are also at risk of catching on fire and must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or else catch fire. A creature that is on fire or is wearing or holding something that is on fire takes {@damage 1d8} fire damage at the start of each of its turns, and can take this damage no more than once each turn. A creature can use its action to drop {@condition prone} and extinguish the flames on it. Flames ignited in this way go out when the spell ends or if they leave the cylinder.

spell.name: Conjunction of Mundanity

m.text: an item originally from the material plane, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with one of the many material planes in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range.

Whenever a spell that deals damage begins at, ends inside, passes through, or overlaps with the cylinder, you can use your reaction to attempt to neutralize the spell by making an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The DC for this check is equal to 10 + the level of the spell slot used to cast the spell (DC 10 for cantrips). If you succeed, the spell ends immediately and has no further effect.

As an action on your turn, you can attempt to banish an otherworldly creature in the area. A creature of your choice within the cylinder must succeed on a Charisma saving throw, or else be teleported to its native plane. Humanoids and creatures native to your current plane of existence automatically succeed on this saving throw.

spell.name: Conjunction of Order

m.text: an item originally from a plane of order and law, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of order and law in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. That area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: No attack rolls, ability checks, or saving throws in the area can be made with advantage or disadvantage.
Any rolls that would normally use {@dice 1d20} use {@dice 2d10} instead.

A creature that moves within the cylinder on its turn can only move in one direction that turn and must move its full speed. If it cannot move its full speed in that direction (for example, if it would be blocked by a wall), it cannot move in that direction at all.

spell.name: Conjunction of Shadow

m.text: an item originally from a plane of shadow or lethargy, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of shadow and lethargy in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. That area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: Creatures in the cylinder's area are immune to the {@condition frightened} and {@condition charmed} conditions. If a creature is {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed} when it is in the area of the spell, the effect causing that condition ends.
All saving throws made in the cylinder against effects that deal necrotic damage are made with advantage or disadvantage (your choice when you cast the spell).

When a humanoid creature dies in the cylinder, it immediately becomes a {@creature zombie} under your mental control. All zombies created in this manner share your initiative count, but act immediately after you. These zombies return to mundane corpses when the spell ends or if they leave the cylinder.

entries: When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can cause one of the following effects:

items: The cylinder fills with magical darkness until you dispel it as a bonus action or until the spell ends. If this effect overlaps with an area of light created by a spell of 5th level or lower, the spell that created the light is dispelled.

Each creature in the cylinder must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be stricken with extreme lethargy. A creature that fails this saving throw wastes its next turn doing nothing. Undead and constructs are immune to this effect.

spell.name: Conjunction of the Natural

m.text: an item originally from a plane of flora and fauna, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of flora and fauna in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. That area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: All creatures in the area are under the effects of a {@spell speak with animals} spell and can communicate with plants, as if by the {@spell speak with plants} spell.
The effects of the {@spell awaken} spell are suppressed within the cylinder.
Each beast or plant creature gains 10 temporary hit points at the start of each of its turns while it is within the cylinder.

All nonmagical terrain in the cylinder either becomes difficult terrain or normal terrain for the duration of the spell (your choice when you cast the spell). The ground may turn rough and rocky, dense foliage may temporarily thin out, or some other natural effect of your choosing occurs.

spell.name: Conjunction of the Nexus

m.text: an item originally from a plane of connection and travel, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of connection and travel in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foot-tall cylinder centered at a point within range. The area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: Each creature in the cylinder can use its bonus action to teleport to an unoccupied space that it can see within the cylinder.
All creatures within the area have disadvantage on saving throws against being teleported against their will (such as by the {@spell banishment} or {@spell plane shift} spells).

spell.name: Conjunction of the Other Side

m.text: an item originally from a plane of judgment or afterlife, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of judgment and afterlife in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foottall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. That area is under the following effects for the duration of the spell:

items: Each corpse in the area is under the effects of a {@spell speak with dead} spell for the duration, without a limit of the number of questions it can be asked.
All creatures in the area make death saving throws with either advantage or disadvantage (your choice when you cast the spell).

entries: When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can summon spirits from beyond the grave. A random incorporeal undead appears in an unoccupied space of your choice within the area. It is indifferent to all other creatures, but will defend itself if attacked. The creatures disappear if they leave the cylinder or when the spell ends. To determine what type of undead appears, roll {@dice 1d12} and consult the following table.

spell.name: Conjunction of Water

m.text: an item originally from a plane of water, worth at least 10 gp

entries: You begin to merge your current plane of existence with a plane of elemental water in a 30-foot-radius, 60-foottall cylinder centered on a point that you can see within range. It is perpetually raining within this cylinder, and all nonmagical fires are extinguished. A creature that is wet within this cylinder has disadvantage on saving throws against cold or lightning damage. This water disappears when the spell ends or if it leaves the cylinder.
When you cast the spell, and as your action each round for the duration, you can cause one of the following effects:

items: You magically conjure {@dice 1d4} {@creature ice mephit||ice mephits}, {@creature mud mephit||mud mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit||steam mephits} (your choice) in unoccupied spaces of your choice within the cylinder. They are hostile to all creatures that are not elementals and act on their own initiative count. These mephits lack the Summon Mephits action. A mephit summoned in this way disappears when the spell ends or if it leaves the cylinder.
You mentally command all mephits summoned by this spell to immediately die, triggering their Death Burst traits.

You fill the cylinder with magical fog, as if by the {@spell fog cloud} spell. This fog dissipates when the spell ends or when you dispel it as a bonus action, and cannot be blown away by a strong wind.

You cause the water on all surfaces in the cylinder to freeze. These surfaces count as difficult terrain, and any creature that makes a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check, Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check, or that takes the {@action Dash} action on an icy surface must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save the creature falls {@condition prone} immediately after completing the check or action and takes {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage. On a successful save, nothing happens.

spell.name: Conjure Greater Animals
entries: You summon a fey spirit that takes the form of a beast or swarm of beasts and appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. You choose the type of beast or swarm of beasts, which must be of challenge rating rating 5 or lower, such as a {@creature giant shark} or {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes}.

The beast is also considered fey, and it disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends. The summoned creature is friendly to you and your companions. It rolls its own initiative and has its own turns, but obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to it, it defends itself from hostile creatures, but otherwise takes no actions.
The DM has the creature's statistics.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 1 for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Dancing Decoy

m.text: a tiny clockwork puppet worth at least 50 gp

entries: You toss a clockwork puppet to an unoccupied space that you can see within range. When you cast this spell, you can designate any number of creatures you can see to be unaffected by it, seeing the object for what it really is. To others, the decoy projects the illusion of a medium humanoid of your choice that performs a taunting dance or an intimidating gesture goading them to fight it. As a bonus action on your turn, you can mentally command the puppet to move up to 20 feet.

Creatures that start their turn within 10 feet of the puppet must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is compelled to move toward the decoy and make a melee weapon attack against it, believing it to be the primary threat. Attacks against the illusion harmlessly flow through the illusion and do not usually damage the puppet, though exceptions can occur. On a successful save, a creature realizes that the projected humanoid is an illusion and becomes immune to the effects of this spell for 24 hours. Creatures that are immune to the {@condition charmed} condition automatically succeed on this save. The effect on a creature also ends if it takes any damage.

spell.name: Dartak's Retribution

time.condition: which you take when you would take fire or lightning damage

entries: This spell draws in and encapsulates combustive energy, protecting you from and wreathing you in fire or lightning from a single source. You grant resistance to the triggering damage to yourself and any creatures you choose within 30 feet of you. You can also choose to immediately channel that fire or lightning away from you in a 5-foot wide, 90-foot long line. If you do, each creature within the line must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@dice 6d6} of the respective damage type on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Detect Portal
entries: You detect the nearest portal within 1 mile of you and learn the following information about it:

items: Its location
Its destination (both the plane it leads to and the exact location on that plane)
If it requires certain circumstances or items to use, you learn what those circumstances or items are.
If it requires a password to use, you learn that it requires a password but do not learn the password.
Whether it is temporary, such as portals cast by the {@spell gate} spell, or permanent

entries: This spell does not detect non-portal teleportation magic, such as teleportation circles.

spell.name: Dismantle
entries: This spell breaks or tears a nonmagical object worth up to 10gp. The break or tear can be up to 1 foot in any dimension.

Make a melee spell attack roll to cast this spell on a construct. On a hit, this spell deals {@damage 2d6} force damage. This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 3d6}), 11th level ({@dice 4d6}), and 17th level ({@dice 5d6}).

spell.name: Elminster's Evoked Delivery

m.text: a small bit of sealing wax, which the spell consumes

entries: You instantaneously shunt an object through the fabric of space to a willing creature with which you are familiar. The object can be no larger than 1 foot on a side and weigh no more than 10 pounds. When you cast the spell, the recipient is magically informed what the object is. If the creature is willing, the object appears in empty space within 5 feet of the creature (the creature's choice). If the creature is on another plane of existence, is {@condition incapacitated}, is proofed against magical detection or location, or is unwilling to receive the object, the spell fails.
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the maximum dimensions increase by both 1 foot on each side and 10 pounds for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Folk Rite

m.text: 25gp in herbs, incense and other materials, consumed by the spell

entries: You perform a ritual of folk magic designed to bring the blessings of gods or spirits on those who take part.

entries.name: Blessing of the Exorcism
entries: One individual you touch who is {@condition charmed} or possessed may immediately make a saving throw against that effect (as the original saving throw), ending the effect on a success. Once a creature receives this blessing, it cannot do so again for 7 days.

entries.name: Blessing of the Faithful
entries: You perform a worship service with a number of creatures up to your caster level, all of whom must be within 30 feet of you for the duration of the spell. Those creatures gain advantage on their next saving throw against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} for the next 24 hours. Once a creature receives this blessing, it cannot do so again for 7 days.

entries.name: Blessing of the Feast
entries: You partake in a feast with a number of creatures up to your caster level, all of whom must be within 30 feet for the duration of the spell. Those creatures may add {@dice 1d4} to an ability check, attack roll or saving throw within the next 24 hours. If those creatures have spent at least 24 hours fasting (abstaining from eating, drinking or other specific behaviours as defined by your faith) before taking part in this ceremony, they may add {@dice 1d4} to one of each of those rolls within the next 24 hours. Once a creature receives this blessing, it cannot do so again for 30 days.

entries.name: Blessing of the Hearth
entries: You ward a single structure, or part of a larger structure, which fits within a 50 foot cube that you are in when you cast this spell. For 7 days after the casting, a creature that finishes a long rest inside the area may add {@dice 1d4} to any skill checks or saving throws made while in the area. Once a structure has been blessed in this way, it cannot be blessed in this way again for one year.

entries.name: Blessing of Industry
entries: You bless a vehicle, musical instrument, or set of artisan's tools, that you can see, selected when you cast the spell. Each day for the following week, a creature using the equipment may add {@dice 1d4} to a single check using that object. Once a creature has an object belonging to them blessed in this way, they may not have another object of the same type blessed for another year. (So, an individual may have a brewers kit blessed, then a boat blessed, but may not have their brewers kit blessed again for a year).

entries.name: Blessing of the Pilgrim
entries: You touch a creature, giving it protection for an upcoming voyage. For the next 7 days, that creature may add {@dice 1d4} to any saving throws they make against {@condition exhaustion} or inclement weather, provided that they are traveling to a single destination during that time. If they change destinations or reach their destination during that time, this effect ends. Once a creature receives this blessing, it cannot do so again for 30 days.

entries.name: Blessing of the Sick
entries: You bless one creature you touch that is afflicted with a disease or poison. The creature immediately makes a saving throw against the effect with advantage. Once a creature receives this blessing, it cannot do so again for a day.

spell.name: Illusory Wall
entries: You create an illusion of a vertical surface that is up to 60 feet long, 10 feet high, and 1 foot thick. The wall can include gaps and openings such as windows, peepholes, and doorways, but they are considered to be holes in the illusion as well. You can use a bonus action to move some or all of the gaps and openings, create new ones, or close the existing ones, but remember that the illusion can only be 1 foot across at its thickest point.

Physical interaction with the wall reveals it to be an illusion, and a creature that uses its action to examine the wall can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the creature can see through the wall. Otherwise, the opaque sections block line of sight.

spell.name: Nystul's False Trail

m.text: *A lump of sulphur, psychedelic fungus, or tarnished silver worth at least 15gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You choose a creature, an object, or a place within range and create an illusion no larger than a 100 ft cube. If an {@spell arcane eye}, {@spell clairvoyance}, {@spell scrying} spell, or similar magic would perceive the target, it instead perceives the illusion that you created when you cast this spell. This illusion can only be perceived by that type of magic, and does not affect creatures perceiving the target through nonmagical means. The illusion can include visuals, sounds, smells, tastes, and other stimuli, but it cannot deal damage or impose conditions.
For example, you could cast this spell on an area that includes the hallway of a gang's hideout, allowing you to walk through that hallway without notifying the warlock guards who are scrying on it.

Suspicious creatures can attempt a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check against your spell save DC. On a success, they realize it's an illusion, but cannot perceive past the illusion. If the spell is cast on a creature or object, it follows that creature or object.
Casting this spell on the same area every day for 30 days makes this effect permanent.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the illusion can be 100 ft larger for each spell level above 4th.

spell.name: Telegrab
entries: You magically teleport a nonmagical object that you can see within range into your hands. You must be able to carry the object, and you must have your hands free. The object cannot weigh more than a number of pounds equal to ten times your Strength score. If it is being carried or worn by a creature, the creature must succeed on a Charisma saving throw, or else the object is teleported into your hands.

spell.name: Tenser's Climbing Wall
entries: A series of opaque handholds appear within range on any surface, including a moving or dangerous surface such as a waterfall or fire, and lasts for the duration. You can make a series of handholds up to 120 feet long. A creature using the handholds gains +10 to ability checks involving climbing.

spell.name: Wall of Bones

components.m: finger bones from a dozen distinct hands

entries: You create a wall of grasping skeletal arms. The wall appears within range on a solid surface and lasts for the duration. You choose to make the wall up to 30 feet long, 10 feet high, and 5 feet thick or a circle that has a 20-foot diameter and is up to 20 feet high and 5 feet thick. The wall blocks line of sight. A creature that is within 5 feet of the wall when the wall is created, or that ends its turn within 5 feet of the wall, must succeed on a Strength saving throw or else take {@damage 2d4} slashing damage and be {@condition restrained} by the grasping arms. A {@condition restrained} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success, or takin {@damage 2d4} slashing damage on a failed save. Each 5-foot-square section has AC 5, 15 hit points, and vulnerability to bludgeoning damage. Reducing a section to 0 hit points destroys that section of the wall and frees a creature {@condition restrained} by it.

spell.name: Wall of Mist
entries: You create a wall of dense fog. You can make the wall up to 60 feet long, 10 feet high, and 5 feet thick. The wall is opaque, and its area is heavily obscured. It lasts for the duration or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it.

spell.name: Waterspout

m.text: a waterskin filled with water, worth at least 1sp

entries: A blast of water leaps from its vessel to strike a foe and pull them off their feet. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or else take {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d6}), 11th level ({@dice 3d6}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d6}).

spell.name: Zap
entries: A stroke of electricity forming a line 30 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d6} lightning damage. The electricity ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
This spell's damage increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d6}), 11th level ({@dice 3d6}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d6}).

ac.special: 11 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier

hp.special: your Constitution modifier + eight times your druid level

trait.name: Ability Scores
entries: Your ability scores remain the same.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk ms} the attack roll bonus is equal to your Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}slashing damage equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Line Breath Weapon (Black, Blue, Brass, Bronze, Copper, Gold only)
entries: You exhale a dangerous blast in a 60 foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, or else take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage of your Dragon Type's damage type. The damage for this attack increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach certain levels in this class: 6th level ({@dice 3d6}), 9th level ({@dice 4d6}), 12th level ({@dice 5d6}), and 18th level ({@dice 7d6}).

action.name: Cone Breath Weapon (Green, Red, Silver, White only)
entries: You exhale a dangerous blast in a 30 foot cone. Each creature in that line must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC, or else take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage of your Dragon Type's damage type. The damage for this attack increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach certain levels in this class: 6th level ({@dice 3d6}), 9th level ({@dice 4d6}), 12th level ({@dice 5d6}), and 18th level ({@dice 7d6}).

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of your choice within 60 feet of you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or else become {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute. A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. A creature that succeeds on this save is immune to the effects of your Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

ac.special: 11 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier

hp.special: your Constitution modifier + five times your druid level

trait.name: Ability Scores
entries: Your ability scores remain the same.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk ms} the attack roll bonus is equal to your Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}slashing damage equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Line Breath Weapon (Black, Blue, Brass, Bronze, Copper, Gold only)
entries: You exhale a dangerous blast in a 30 foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, or else take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage of your Dragon Type's damage type. The damage for this attack increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach certain levels in this class: 6th level ({@dice 3d6}), 9th level ({@dice 4d6}), 12th level ({@dice 5d6}), and 18th level ({@dice 7d6}).

action.name: Cone Breath Weapon (Green, Red, Silver, White only)
entries: You exhale a dangerous blast in a 15 foot cone. Each creature in that line must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC, or else take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage of your Dragon Type's damage type. The damage for this attack increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach certain levels in this class: 6th level ({@dice 3d6}), 9th level ({@dice 4d6}), 12th level ({@dice 5d6}), and 18th level ({@dice 7d6}).

trait.name: Swarm Heart Sight
entries: The swarm automatically knows the current emotional state of any creature it touches. If a target fails a {@dc 10} Charisma saving throw, the sprite also knows the creature's alignment. Celestials, fiends, and undead automatically fail the saving throw.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny sprite. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes three weapon attacks.

action.name: Vanguard
entries: {@atk mw} +6 to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) slashing damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) slashing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Volley
entries: {@atk rw} +6 to hit, range 40/160 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. On a hit, the target creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. If it fails its saving throw by 5 or more, the {@condition poisoned} creature falls unonscious for the same duration, or until it takes damage or another creature takes an

action.name: Lift
entries: The swarm attempts to grab a creature or object within its space. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, or else be {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained} by the swarm. This does not make the swarm {@condition grappled}. The swarm can magically lift any Medium creature or object that weighs 500 pounds or less.

action.name: Plummet
entries: The swarm drops any number of creatures it is holding. It takes coordination for dozens of creatures to drop something simultaneously; the swarm cannot willingly drop a creature or object except by taking this action.

table.name: Variant: Flaws
table.caption: Variant: Flaws
intro: Strengths and weaknesses are one of the many ways every person is unique. If you would like for your character's flaws to affect its ability checks, consider taking one of the following Mechanical Flaws in addition to or instead of the flaws you would normally take for your character. You can choose from the following table or roll for a random result.

entries.name: Smells Like Meat
entries: You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks.

entries.name: Left-Brained
entries: You have disadvantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks.

entries.name: Bad Poker Face
entries: You have disadvantage on Charisma (Deception) checks.

entries.name: Forgetful
entries: You have disadvantage on Intelligence (History) checks.

entries.name: Gullible
entries: You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Insight) checks.

entries.name: Adorable
entries: You have disadvantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks.

entries.name: Queasy
entries: You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Medicine) checks.

entries.name: Black Thumb
entries: You have disadvantage on Intelligence (Nature) checks.

entries.name: Nearsighted
entries: You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight made to perceive things farther than 10 feet away from you. This does not affect your attack rolls.

entries.name: Farsighted
entries: You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight made to perceive things 10 feet or closer to you. This does not affect your attack rolls.

entries.name: Stage-Frightened
entries: You have disadvantage on Charisma (Performance) checks.

entries.name: Shifty-Eyed
entries: You have disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks.

entries.name: Aggressive
entries: Any time you make a Charisma (Persuasion) check, there is a 50% chance you make a Charisma (Intimidation) check instead.

entries.name: Skeptic
entries: You have disadvantage on Intelligence (Religion) checks.

entries.name: Clumsy
entries: You have disadvantage on Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) checks.

entries.name: City Slicker
entries: You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks.

entries.name: Country Bumpkin
entries: You have disadvantage on checks made to navigate urban areas, use public facilities in cities, or interact with bureaucracies.

entries.name: Acrophobic
entries: You have disadvantage on ability checks made to climb things.

entries.name: Skittish
entries: You have disadvantage on ability checks made against being frightened or intimidated.

entries.name: Unlucky
entries: When you roll a 20 on the d20 for an ability check, you must reroll the die and use the new result.

entries.name: Suspicious
entries: You've got that look about you. They don't know what you've done, but you've probably done something.

entries.name: Associate
entries: You're known to the local law enforcers. They keep an eye on you when they get the chance.

entries.name: Active Investigation
entries: There is now an active investigation into some of your criminal activities. You have Disadvantage to all Downtime Crime Activities except Laying Low rolls.

entries.name: Identified Suspect
entries: They have your name and know your face. If you are seen by law enforcement, they will approach you. If you run, they will chase you.

entries.name: Wanted
entries: Law enforcement is actively looking for you. If you spend more than 24 hours in the same location, they will know your current location, and agents or officers will soon arrive there to detain you.

entries.name: Hunted
entries: You are actively pursued by law enforcement in and outside of the location of your crimes. Other settlements have heard of you.

table.name: Doing Time Outcome
table.caption: Doing Time Outcome
rows: You got into more trouble. Your sentence has been extended.
You made enemies on the inside. When you come out, their people will be after you.
You sustained a serious injury and now have the scar to prove it.
You were moved to a jail in a different region.
The jailer took pity on you. Your time was unremarkable.
Your cellmate was a highly renowned tutor before they turned to crime. You gain proficiency in one new tool or language.
You befriend an old crimelord on the inside. They gave you a map that supposedly leads to their buried stash. They're never getting out.
You shared a cell with an underling for a very powerful crimelord, and they owe you a favor.

table.name: Laying Low Complications
table.caption: Laying Low Complications
rows: Your hideout is raided and can no longer be used.
You had to flee quickly and lost an item valuable to you.
An associate of yours was caught. They could talk or they might blame you.
The guard let you go... for a price. See the Bribery section above.
Your infamy has drawn a crimelord's attention, and they don't like you. Perhaps they are a new rival.
You are apprehended and must serve time appropriate to your crimes and infamy level.

table.name: Lifepath: Upbringing
table.caption: Upbringing
rows: You are an orphan. Forced to fend for yourself, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Survival} skill.
Your family is extremely wealthy. You gain the {@background noble||Position of Privilege} background feature.

Your family is multilingual, and you grew up speaking multiple languages. You speak one standard {@filter language|languages|source=PHB} of your choice from chapter 4 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}.
Your family made a pact with demons or a deal with a devil, many generations ago. You speak your choice of {@language Abyssal} or {@language Infernal}.
You inherited the service of loyal retainers who have served your family for generations. You gain the {@background variant noble (knight)||Retainers} background feature.

Your family has worked and lived on the sea for generations. Although you may know nothing about sailing, you gain the {@background sailor||Ship's Passage} background fature. Veteran seafarers respect your family name, if not yourself.

table.name: Lifepath: Childhood
table.caption: Childhood

entries: You grew up in an area containing an enclave of a minority group. Roll {@dice 1d8} (or choose a result) to find out which group; you speak that group's language.
1: Humans ({@language Common})
2: Dwarves ({@language Dwarvish})
3: Elves ({@language Elvish})
4: Halflings ({@language Halfling})
5: Gnomes ({@language Gnomish})
6: Goblins ({@language Goblin})
7: Orcs ({@language Orc})
8: Dragonborn ({@language Draconic})

rows: You have a childhood friend who never seemed to be able to take the right path. You gain the {@background criminal||Criminal Contact} background feature.
You have a literal guardian angel. Or at least, you did when you were a child. You haven't seen them for a long time. You speak the {@language Celestial} language.
You were left to run wild in the streets. You gain the {@background urchin||City Streets} background feature.
You had free time to play games as a child. You gain proficiency in a {@item gaming set|phb} of your choice.
You enjoyed making music as a child. If you didn't have a real musical instrument, you improvised your own. You gain proficiency with a {@item musical instrument|phb} of your choice.

table.name: Lifepath: Adolescence
table.caption: Adolescence
rows: You were apprenticed early. You gain proficiency in one type of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.
You were the leader of the children you grew up with. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill.
You got lost in the wilderness a lot. But you always found your way back home. You gain the {@background outlander||Wanderer} background feature.
You had to do the cooking. You gain proficiency in {@item cook's utensils|phb}.
You were a lookout. Were you waiting for your friends to welcome them or watching for your enemies? You gain proficiency in the {@skill Perception} skill.
You carved small wooden items. Was it just for fun, or did you need to do carving for some reason? You gain proficiency in {@item woodcarver's tools|phb}.
You were very active, running and climbing everywhere. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill.
You spent much of your adolescence lying and deflecting blame. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Deception} skill.

table.name: Lifepath: Formal Education
table.caption: Formal Education
rows: You attended a school for young wizards. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill.
You took lessons at the local temple. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Religion} skill.
Circumstances forced you to learn how to examine evidence, rather than listen to the people around you, to learn what is true. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Investigation} skill.
A druid, hermit, herbalist, or other such mentor taught you and other children the details of the wild. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Nature} skill.
You were taught the basics of tumbling, rope-walking, and other such tricks by an acrobat or circus. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Acrobatics} skill.
You were taught lessons in the history of the world. They may or may not have been totally accurate. You gain proficiency in the {@skill History} skill.
You didn't pay attention to your lessons. You were too busy bullying the other children. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skill.

You had a cruel teacher whose whims ruled their classroom, rather than facts. You didn't learn whatever they were supposed to teach you, but you learned how to read them to avoid punishment. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight} skill.

table.name: Lifepath: Early Occupation
table.caption: Early Occupation
rows: Apprenticeship wasn't for you. Instead, you picked pockets. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Sleight of Hand} skill.
You were apprenticed to a blacksmith. You gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|phb}.
You were apprenticed to a juggler, singer, bard, or other performer. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Performance} skill.
You spent time in the fields, hauling rocks, or otherwise doing manual labor. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill.
You worked in a stable. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill.
You were apprenticed to the local midwife, wise woman, doctor, or other healer. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Medicine} skill.
You were taken under the wing of a local thief, gang of thieves, or other collection of skullduggers. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill.
You were trained in the art of etiquette and public speaking in preparation for your adult life. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill.

table.name: Lifepath: Professional Work
table.caption: Professional Work
rows: Consult the {@table Work - The Arcane|TCEE1} table
Consult the {@table Work - The Divine|TCEE1} table
Consult the {@table Work - Trade and Culture|TCEE1} table
Consult the {@table Work - The Wilds|TCEE1} table

table.name: Lifepath: Any Age
table.caption: Any Age
rows: You saved a small village, or a poor neighborhood, or other group of common folk, from a monster attack or other danger. You gain the {@background folk hero||Rustic Hospitality} background feature.
There are horrible rumors about you and the things you have done. Are they true? You gain the {@background variant sailor (pirate)||Bad Reputation} background feature.
You were shipwrecked on a deserted island, trapped in an avalanche, left on a mountain, or otherwise alone in the wilderness by accident. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Survival} skill.

You were forced to take the metaphorical wheel when the driver of a vehicle you were in was suddenly incapacitated. You gain proficiency in your choice of {@filter land vehicles|items|type=vehicle (land)} or {@filter water vehicles|items|type=vehicle (water)}.
You were captured and left to die in a prison. You taught yourself how to pick the lock to escape. You gain proficiency in {@item thieves' tools|phb}.
You somehow ended up in a competition for the sake of your soul. Did you win? You gain proficiency in your choice of a {@item gaming set|phb} or a {@item musical instrument|phb}.

table.name: Work - The Arcane
table.caption: Work - The Arcane
rows: Your magical research has unlocked the secrets of alchemy. You gain proficiency with your choice of the {@item herbalism kit|phb}, {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}, or {@item brewer's supplies|phb}.
One way or another, you found yourself in possession of a fundamental truth about the multiverse. You gain the {@background hermit||Discovery} background feature.
You found yourself in an arcane profession without a firm grounding in the basics, and spent some time catching up. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill.
You experimented with, or were taught, traditions of magical music and musical magic. You gain proficiency with your choice of one {@item musical instrument|phb} or the {@skill Performance} skill.
You have spent what seems like lifetimes surrounded by tomes of knowledge. You gain the {@background sage||Researcher} background feature.

You have experimented with, or been taught, or otherwise learned, traditions of artifice telling you that using objects you created yourself smooths the magic. You gain proficiency in a set of {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice.

table.name: Work - The Divine
table.caption: Work - The Divine
rows: You have sworn oaths to a temple or other religious organization. You gain the {@background acolyte||Shelter of the Faithful} background feature.
You served as an officer in a temple's military force. You gain the {@background soldier||Military Rank} background feature.

You learned not only the doctrine of your religion, but the doctrine of other religions and the history of your and other religions in the world. You gain proficiency in your choice of the {@skill Religion} skill or the {@skill History} skill.
You preached fire and brimstone to scare people into converting to your religious organization. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skill.
You served as a healer. Did you heal the rich who could pay, the influential who could convince you, or anyone who needed it? You gain proficiency in the {@skill Medicine} skill.

You came from common folk and made sure that you could stay somewhere to help them, even at the cost of advancement within your organization. You gain the {@background folk hero||Rustic Hospitality} background feature.

table.name: Work - Skulduggery
table.caption: Work - Skulduggery
rows: You have spent time creating a second identity for yourself. You gain the {@background charlatan||False Identity} background feature.
You used your skills to uncover information. Did you serve a kingdom or organization, or just sell it? You gain the {@background criminal||Criminal Contact} background feature.
You know everything there is to know about poisons. Do you use them yourself, or defend against them? You gain proficiency with the {@item poisoner's kit|phb}.

You were a pickpocket or con man. Did you rob from the rich and give to the poor, or just rob from the poor and keep it? You gain proficiency in your choice of the {@skill Sleight of Hand} skill or the {@skill Deception} skill.
You've had experience escaping from ropes, holds, and other restraints. You certainly weren't doing anything illegal. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Acrobatics} skill.
You consider keys a nice convenience, but not required if you want a lock open. You gain proficiency with {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

table.name: Work - Trade and Culture
table.caption: Work - Trade and Culture
rows: You became a recognized artisan in your craft. If you do not already have proficiency in any artisan's tools, gain proficiency in one type of {@item artisan's tools|phb}. If you do, gain the {@background guild artisan||Guild Membership} background feature.
You are a famous and recognized entertainer. You gain the {@background entertainer||By Popular Demand} background feature.
You are a silver-tongued negotiator. Are you famous for this? You gain proficiency in your choice of the {@skill Persuasion} skill or the {@skill Insight} skill.
You traveled widely. As the saying goes, you've been everywhere. You gain your choice of proficiency in {@item navigator's tools|phb} or the {@background outlander||Wanderer} background feature.
You have many contacts with sailors. Did you serve on a ship yourself or just hire them? You gain the {@background sailor||Ship's Passage} background feature.
No irregularity in records or undeclared cargo can evade your eye. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Investigation} skill.

table.name: Work - War
table.caption: Work - War
rows: You served as a quartermaster in a military force. You gain proficiency with {@filter land vehicles|items|type=vehicle (land)}.

You were personally a scourge of the high seas or of the land, or you served with a unit or force with that reputation. You gain the {@background variant sailor (pirate)||Bad Reputation} background feature.

You were a scout. Did you always find enough, or did something important slip by that you'll always regret? You gain proficiency in your choice of the {@skill Perception} skill or the {@skill Stealth} skill.
You were a navigator, pathfinder, or otherwise in charge of directions for your unit. You gain proficiency in {@item navigator's tools|phb}.
You marched all day and fought all night. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill.
You were an officer in a military organization. You gain the {@background soldier||Military Rank} background feature.

table.name: Work - The Wilds
table.caption: Work - The Wilds
rows: You have spent a great deal of time in the wilderness, and their secrets are known to you. You gain your choice of the {@background outlander||Wanderer} background feature or proficiency in the {@skill Survival} skill.
You have made a study of the wild and the things in them. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Nature} skill.
You have spent much time in isolation and some form of enlightenment has come to you. You gain the {@background hermit||Discovery} background feature.
You cook for yourself, usually using things that you grew, gathered, or hunted yourself. You gain proficiency in {@item cook's utensils|phb}.
You need to keep your eyes open to survive in the wild. Do you bear any marks from times when you didn't? You gain proficiency in the {@skill Perception} skill.
You have a rapport with animals. Do you use it to make friends with animals, or just to keep them away from you? You gain proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill.

variantrule.name: Downtime Crime Revisited
entries: The following are a selection of criminal activities that adventurers who walk in the grey areas of morality might choose to engage in. This by no means suggests that players must engage in these activities. These activities revolve around increasing monetary wealth in illegal and immoral ways. But they do bring in gold. They are not senseless crimes. Crime for the sake of crime brings unnecessary infamy and makes earning ill gotten gains increasingly difficult.
Clever criminals don't want infamy. They want money.

entries.name: Environmental Implications
entries: Depending on where someone is in the world will impact what they are able to do and possible impacts from the activities.

entries.name: Wilderness
entries: You're out in the wild. There's usually no one around. Good. What you want to do requires time and space. This is great for alchemical endeavors or crafting, however there are certain activities that just won't work out here.

entries.name: Small Villiage
entries: There is trade and commerce here that is just asking to have its profits skimmed. The added bonus is that it's unlikely to have guards, maybe a poorly trained militia at best. But who is in this milita? Old people with farming tools. Ultimately, word will get out and someone will come to clean up the mess you're making.

entries.name: Town
entries: More people means more gold. A town gives you access to more opportunities. There is often a town guard, but you can always try to pay them off. You are more likely to find lords and nobles nearby who can act as patrons or victims. Towns are usually connected to a larger city in some way, so be prepared for interference should your activities get noticed.

entries.name: City
entries: Every city is ripe fruit with a rotten core. In a city you can blend in and disappear, or you can be the center of attention, it is your choice. That's what a city has to offer: options. You can be involved in any sort of crime in a city, but you will have to deal with other gangs and law enforcement. Both of these either want you out or want your money.

entries.name: Infamy
entries: The best criminals are those that are not seen. Those whose names are secret and faces are hidden.The problem is that they do not remain that way. Accidents happen, treachery is always around the corner, and the watch is always watching. When things go wrong your name gets out there. Every fumble leads to a little notoriety, every misstep adds to the pressure. Eventually, the watch will be after you.
The {@table infamy levels|TCEE1} table outlines the levels of infamy and the impact they may have on the character.

entries.name: Reducing Infamy
entries: There are a number of ways to reduce the infamy you have acquired. The Dungeon Master will help to decide what will work and how effective the approach will be. These are just some suggestions; players are encouraged to be creative when reducing infamy.

entries.name: Bribes
entries: There are dirty guards everywhere and they want your gold too. Depending on the crime, some gold might be enough to reduce your heat. Some crimes are too serious to be covered up with gold after the fact.

entries.caption: Bribe Costs
rows: You cannot pay your way out of this level.
You cannot pay your way out of this level.

entries.name: Doing Time
entries: Doing time will reduce your infamy, but you won't be doing anything else. Time served will vary depending on crimes committed and your social standing with the local law enforcement. An appropriate length of time should be discussed and negotiated with the DM. Players may also like to roleplay a trial.

While inside there are many things that may happen to you. While behind bars, time does not stand still, and events that occur on the inside might have lasting consequences. Some of these events might be beneficial, but others are detrimental to you, impacting you negatively either immediately or in the future. Being locked in a dungeon or jail is a testing time and everyone who goes in comes out changed. They have experiences and meet people that impact them. At the end of the character's sentence they can roll on the {@table Doing Time Outcome|TCEE1} table.

entries.name: Laying Low
entries: Sometimes you just have to get out of town. You can leave town and start fresh somewhere else to let everything settle down. Once your face is forgotten and your name is now longer on everyone's lips you can return. However, depending on what you do that might take a long time.

It takes 1 month of laying low and a successful skill check to reduce one level of infamy. The player can use any skill they like but it should connect narratively with what they are attempting to do. The character must add all appropriate modifiers and then roll on the Laying Low table.

entries.name: Complications
entries: On a failed Laying Low check, you do not reduce your Infamy level and instead must roll on the {@table Laying Low Complications|TCEE1} table. Use these complications to help build a narrative that explains why the character has not been successful in their attempt to lay low. They also open up opportunities to create a rival using {@variantrule Downtime Revisited|XGE} in of {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE}.

items: {@variantrule Crime Activity: Extortion/Protection Racket|TCEE1}
{@variantrule Crime Activity: Counterfeiting|TCEE1}
{@variantrule Crime Activity: Street Level Dealing|TCEE1}
{@variantrule Crime Activity: Underworld Alchemy|TCEE1}

variantrule.name: Crime Activity: Extortion/Protection Racket
entries: Protection rackets: the bread and butter of an organized crime outfittion rackets. The streets are dangerous, and you are there to help. You offer your services as protector ensuring that nothing will happen to their establishment. If they don't want to pay that's fine, unfortunate, but fine. They will just have to deal with their problems themselves. And there will be problems. Because you'll be making them.
It's the perfect set up. You get paid to offer protection from yourself. Surely, nothing could go wrong.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The character identifies the shop, store, or business they want to extort. They will then have to approach the owner and offer their 'services'. The player must choose an appropriate skill at the DM's discretion, such as Intimidation, and make an ability check. The difficulty depends on how much money they are attempting to extort from the shop owner. They set the amount they wish to extort and then roll on the Extortion table. The amounts on the table are a guideline and can be adjusted depending on location.

entries.name: Complications
entries: If the character fails the check, they do not get a lower amount. They have failed to extort the shop owner and will not be collecting any protection money. The character must roll on the Protection Racket Complications table.

entries.caption: Protection Racket Complications
rows: The store owner is the fence of another criminal organization, they tell you who they work for. This may be a new rival.
The shop owner is connected. They tell you to leave, which crew they are with, and that you've made an enemy.
The shop owner is related to law enforcement, gain 2 levels of infamy.
The shop owner starts to yell and draws attention from law enforcement. Gain 1 level of infamy.
Another customer walks into the store, realises what's going on, and calls the guard. Gain 1 level of infamy.
A customer walks into the store and asks what's going on. It's one of your companions.

variantrule.name: Crime Activity: Counterfeiting
entries: Everyone is looking for a bargain, and the counterfeiter is happy to supply one, with a lower quality product to boot. A low quality version or cheap replica of almost anything can be made, but it takes skill to make it look like it's the real deal.
Craftspersons of every sort have tools available to produce counterfeit products. Below are some examples that characters could experiment with.

entries.name: Alchemist's Supplies
entries: Alchemists have the ability to create low quality potions, poisons, and herbal remedies. While probably harmless, the unwitting adventurer might not realize their health potion is a fake until it's too late.

entries.name: Calligrapher's Supplies
entries: Calligraphy is the art of creating beautifully detailed lettering. A calligrapher might create fake documents and spell scrolls.

entries.name: Cartographer's Supplies
entries: Creating maps to know where. The counterfeit map is a fantastic way to send your problem away. Hopefully, they don't realize it's a fake before they head off.

entries.name: Cobbler's Tools
entries: Sure, these boots are made of the finest leather and come with lifetime guarantee. Unfortunately, no one clarified whose lifetime.

entries.name: Forgery Kit
entries: Reproduce almost any official document. Create convincing seals, copy signatures, and duplicate letters of authenticity.

entries.name: Glassblower's Tools
entries: Create reproductions of famous pieces of art and magic items.

entries.name: Herbalism Kit
entries: A skilled herbalist can create a vast array of nonfunctional remedies with a small amount of material.

entries.name: Jeweler's Tools
entries: With their selection of specialized tools a jeweler can make cheap metal look like the crown jewels.

entries.name: Leatherworker's Tools
entries: The leather worker can turn scraps into shoes, armor, and even 'magic' pendants.

entries.name: Painter's Supplies
entries: The artist has the ability to reproduce famous pieces of art. The best part is that most people have never seen the real thing.

entries.name: Smith's Tools
entries: A skilled smithy can produce a soundlooking weapon or piece of armor from very cheap metals. Said metal may bend or crack at the merest mention of combat, but at lease they look good.

entries.name: Tinker's Tools
entries: Create cheap watches, machines that break down quickly, and faulty devices.

entries.name: Weaver's Tools
entries: Create items of clothing that certainly look like they have magic properties.

entries.name: Woodcarver's tools
entries: Replicate ancient magic idols, sculptures, and tokens.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The character decides what item they want to reproduce and then selects the appropriate kit or tool set. Creating a counterfeit item costs  the price of the item outlined in the PHB or DMG. Items not listed should be negotiated with the DM. For some items this may still be quite expensive, but they have the opportunity to make triple their money back. The character adds all appropriate modifiers and rolls on the Counterfeit Creation table.

entries.name: Failure
entries: The item is not created.

entries.name: Success
entries: The item is easily detectable as a fake. Take a -5 penalty to the selling roll. A complication arises.

entries.name: Success
entries: The item can be identified as fake on close inspection. A complication arises.

entries.name: Success
entries: The item is only noticeable as fake when it doesn't work as intended, usually far away from you. Take a +5 bonus to the selling roll.

Once the item has been created it can be sold. This might be to a specific buyer or to a shop owner or they may hold onto the item for some other reason. Regardless, when the time comes to sell the item the character adds any modifiers gained during the creation and rolls on the Selling Counterfeit Item table. It is important to keep note on who it is sold to as a complication may arise.

entries.name: Complications
entries: Depending on how successful the character has been with their crafting they may need to run into some complications. The character must roll on the Counterfeit Item Complications table.

entries.caption: Counterfeit Item Complications
rows: You have sold to someone closely connected to law enforcement. Gain 2 levels of infamy.
A counterfeit item has been traced back to you. Gain 1 level of infamy.
An item you created has led to the death of an innocent person. Gain 1 level of infamy.
A local artisan has noticed counterfeits of their goods. You have disadvantage on your next sale.
Your item made its way to the dinner party of a noble, where it was identified as a fake. You may have gained a new rival.
You've been asked to speak at a convention of artisans as a result of your 'fine' work. You are unsure if this is legitimate or a ruse to catch you.

variantrule.name: Crime Activity: Street Level Dealing
entries: Illicit substances are sold out on the roads and cobblestone paths. This is a dangerous activity and is often looked down on by other criminals, and especially everyday society.

entries.name: Resolution
entries: The character must pick an appropriate place to attempt this activity. Shady parts of town are ideal and outside the fort is probably a bad idea. However, depending on who they are selling to and what they are selling, this might change. This is a dangerous activity. There is a very high chance they will be caught, eventually.

It takes 1 day and 1 successful skill check to sell 1 unit of the substance. The character can choose which skill they want to use, such as Charisma (Persuasion) or Dexterity (Sleight of Hand), but should fit the narrative of the activity. The player then rolls on the Street Level Dealing table.

entries.caption: Street Level Dealing
rows: Sale. Business is booming. You sell two units.

entries.name: Complication
entries: As is bound to happen with an activity such as this, complications arise. The character rolls on the Street Dealing Complications table.

entries.caption: Street Dealing Complications
rows: The guards are after you! Gain 2 levels of infamy.
A rival attempts to rob you. Lose 25% of the gold you have and gain 1 level of infamy.
